name: General Knowledge 6 Quiz / Test | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: In which Disney film does Tinkerbell appear?
questions.explanation:
Peter Pan.

	Peter Pan was adapted from the book by Sir James M. Barrie and released in February 1953.

questions.text: Which country's flag formerly had a large 'R' on it?
questions.explanation:
Rwanda.

	Rwanda's flag had vertical red, yellow and green colours which symbolized African unity. The 'R' distingished Rwanda's flag from the flag of Guinea.

questions.text: In which city would you find the Trevi Fountain, which was built in 1762 by Nicola Salvi?
questions.explanation:
Rome.

	The central statue represents Oceanus which in Greek mythology was a Titan divinity of the stream believed to flow around the earth.

questions.text: This city in California was the original Disneyland site opened in 1955.
questions.explanation: Anaheim.

questions.text: In the song 'The Twelve Days of Christmas', how many drummers were drumming?
questions.explanation:
Twelve.

	Twelve drummers drumming, eleven pipers piping, ten lords a-leaping, nine ladies dancing, eight maids a-milking, seven swans a-swimming, six geese a-laying, five gold rings, four calling birds, three French hens, two turtle doves and a partridge in a pear tree.

questions.text: In which city would you find the Wailing Wall?
questions.explanation:
Jerusalem.

	This is also called 'Western Wall' which is a place in Jerusalem sacred to all Jews being a focus of many pilgrimages. It is a remnant of a wall of the great Temple destroyed by the Romans in AD 70.

questions.text: Which of the following artists was NOT an impressionist painter?
questions.explanation:
Salvador Dali.

	Dali was an influential exponent of surrealism which uses bizarre imagery to surprise and shock viewers. He also designed jewellery, fabrics and furniture.

questions.text: Which animal's name is derived from a Spanish word meaning 'a small armoured man'?
questions.explanation: Armadillo.

questions.text: Who played the character part of criminal mastermind 'Fearless Leader' in the film 'The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle'?
questions.explanation: Robert deNiro.

questions.text: Name the long narrow inlet of the sea coast found especially in south-west Ireland and north-west Spain?
questions.explanation:
Ria.

	Derived from Spanish 'rio' meaning river.

questions.text: Queen Victoria ruled Britain for 64 years, longer than any other British monarch. How many daughters and sons did she have?
questions.explanation:
4 sons and 5 daughters.

	Edward VII, Alfred, Arthur, Leopold, Victoria, Alice, Helena, Louise and Beatrice.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the number of times each actor has played the role of James Bond?
questions.explanation:
Pierce Brosnan - twice.

	Sean Connery: 'Dr.No', 'From Russia With Love', 'Goldfinger', 'Thunderball', 'You Only Live Twice', 'Diamonds Are Forever' and 'Never Say Never Again'. Roger Moore: 'Live and Let Die', 'The Man with the Golden Gun', 'The Spy who Loved Me', 'Moonraker', 'For Your Eyes Only', 'Octopussy' and 'A View to a Kill' Timothy Dalton: 'The Living Daylights' and 'Licence to Kill' Pierce Brosnan has made four, as of 2002.

questions.text: What was the name of the dog belonging to little orphan Annie?
questions.explanation: Sandy.

questions.text: Name the youngest child of thirteen children of a West Country clergyman who wrote 'Kubla Khan'?
questions.explanation:
Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

	He is best known for 'The Rime of the Ancient Mariner' (1798)

questions.text: The game of polo originated in which country?
questions.explanation:
Persia (Iran).

	Polo originated in Persia in ancient times and was revived in India in the 19th century and taken up by British army officers there.

questions.text: What is measured using a sphygmomanometer?
questions.explanation:
Blood pressure.

	An instrument used to measure arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: How many of the following rivers are located in South America: Colorado, Uruguay, Paraguay and Madeira?
questions.explanation: All four.

questions.text: What was the name of the Dutchman who became director-general of New Amsterdam (later New York City) in 1647?
questions.explanation:
Peter Stuyvesant.

	He became governor of the Caribbean islands of Curacao and Aruba in 1643 and director-general in 1647 of all the Dutch territories including New Amsterdam (later New York City).

questions.text: Name the French composer of the 1925 ballet 'Les Matelots'.
questions.explanation: Georges Auric.

questions.text: Which famous explorer sailed in the ship 'Gjoa'?
questions.explanation:
Roald Amundsen.

	The North West Passage record of voyage of exploration of the ship 'Gjoa' (1903-1907) was written by Roald Amundsen.

questions.text: In 1924 the world's first motorway opened which ran from where to where?
questions.explanation: Milan to Varese.

questions.text: Paper currency first appeared in western China in (960-1279) during which dynasty?
questions.explanation:
Song (Sung).

	During the Yuan dynasty (1206-1367) paper money was used exclusively as metal coins were not permitted.

questions.text: Which country's name means 'land of many rivers'?
questions.explanation: Guyana.

questions.text: Who designed over 300 gardens for wealthy clients, working closely with famous architect Edwin Lutyens?
questions.explanation:
Gertrude Jekyll.

	She originally trained as a painter but had to abandon that career when her eyesight began to fail.

questions.text: The 'Triton' made the first circumnavigation underwater voyage on 25th April 1960. What was the name of her captain? Edward Latimer ... ?
questions.explanation:
Beach.

	Triton followed the route of Ferdinand Magellan for 36,000 miles during 84 days beneath the surface. Hope you enjoyed this tricky quiz.
